fields.descriptive_line: Celestial drummer (gandharva), potstone, Halebid, Mysore, India, early 13th century

fields.name: : L’escultura en els temples indis: l’art de la devocio

fields.physical_description:
This figure is carved almost in the round on a diagonal axis out of a long thin square-sectioned piece of stone. It would have been positioned as part of a niche group, most probably situated on the exterior of a major temple. The musician is tensed and his knees are bent to give support to the drum, in a treatment that gives considerable vitality to the subject. The flamboyant foliage forming a canopy above his head and the extravagant detailing of the jewellery and crown suggest that the sculpture belonged to a temple built in the southern Deccan in the early thirteenth century. Prior to that period the Jains had been slow to exploit the ornate style that had evolved under Hoysala Hindu patronage. This style is especially in evidence on the numerous temples built during the reigns of Hoysala rulers Vira Ballala II (1173-1220) and Narasimha II (1220-39). An exception is the Jain temple of Santisvara Basti in Sravana Belgola, built by Vira Ballala II in the late twelfth century, where celestial drummers are depicted in the external reliefs, breaking with the Jain convention for unadorned temple exteriors.

This unusual sculpture is a cornerpiece and the adroit artist has ingeniously accommodated the form in such a way that the figure is visible from both sides. This may explain why the drummer seemingly strikes an awkward posture in the illustration. Supporting his drum with his left thigh, he grasps it with his left hand, beating the instrument only with his right hand.
fields.dimensions: Height: 139 cm, Width: 26 cm, Depth: 35 cm, Weight: 193 kg

fields.name: South and South East Asian Collection

fields.public_access_description:
This is a figure of a celestial musician (‘gandharva’). These semi-divine beings served as attendants to the principle deity and are a regular feature of both Hindu and Jain temples. 

This sculpture could be accommodated by either faith. It is carved almost in the round and was part of a niche group, most probably situated on the exterior of a major temple. The tensed pose, with knees bent to give support to the drum, gives the figure considerable vitality. 

The flamboyant foliage and the extravagant detail of the jewellery and crown help to date it. They suggest that the sculpture belonged to a temple built in the southern Deccan in the early 13th century. This style can be seen on the numerous temples built during the period 1173-1239. An exception is the Jain temple of Santisvara Basti in Sravana Belgola, built by Vira Ballala II in the late 12th century. Here celestial drummers are depicted in the external reliefs, breaking with the Jain convention for unadorned temple exteriors.
fields.exhibition_history: : L’escultura en els temples indis: l’art de la devocio (CaixaForum, Barcelona 27/07/2007-18/11/2007)
fields.bibliography:
Guy, John (ed.).<u> L’Escultura en els Temples Indis: L’Art de la Devocio</u>, Barcelona : Fundacio ‘La Caixa’, 2007. No. 79, p117. ISBN 9788476649466
The photograph in this publication shows the plaster cast of the object. The plaster cast is painted black.
John Guy, in P.Pal (ed). <u>The Peaceful Liberators, Jain Art from India</u> 1994, p.194. Pratapaditya Pal, <u>Dancing to the Flute, Music and Dance in Indian Art</u>, 1997, p.115/6
fields.history_note: This sculpture was presented to Lady Lethbridge in 1894 by the Diwan of Mysore and was exhibited shortly afterwards in London, possibly at the Empire Exhibition of 1895.
fields.historical_context_note: The gandharva represents a class of semi-divine beings whose role was to serve as attendants to the principal deity. Over time they came to be conceived of principally as musicians and were represented playing a variety of instruments. They are regularly shown attending the main deity or can also appear autonomously in a larger sculptural programme. They are a regular feature of both Hindu and Jain temples; this sculpture could be accommodated by either faith. The Jain gandharva is one type of vyantaradevata, or inferior deity.
